'''Francisco Paesa''' (Madrid, Spain, 11 April 1936- ) is a Spanish former spy<ref>{{cite web| title= El espía Francisco Paesa creó una sociedad 'offshore' tras fingir su muerte| url=http://www.lasexta.com/noticias/papeles-panama/espia-francisco-paesa-creo-sociedad-offshore-fingir-muerte_2016040500367.html}}</ref> and businessman best known for his implication in several corruption scandals and the faking of his own death in the 1990s.
==Biography== He began his business career conducting various businesses with [[Francisco Macías Nguema]], the then dictator of [[Equatorial Guinea]].<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2004/11/15/espana/1100499055.html La azarosa vida del espía 'Paco'] in elmundo.es</ref> In 1976 he was arrested by [[Interpol]] in Belgium and imprisoned in Switzerland and it is believed that he collaborated with the paramilitary group [[GAL (paramilitary group)|GAL]].<ref>[http://www.abc.es/cultura/abci-francisco-paesa-paco-espia-espanol-resucito-y-ahora-aparece-papeles-panama-201605270322_noticia.html Francisco Paesa «Paco», el espía español que resucitó y ahora aparece en los papeles de Panamá ] in abc.es</ref>
===Sokoa Operation=== After serving his [[Sentence (law)|sentence]] in 1986 he posed as an arms dealer who sold two antiaircraft missiles to [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]]. The terrorist group did not know that the missiles had a location signal. The police could find at Henday in France during July 1986 and for the first time, a major hideout in which a large number of weapons and documents were stored. Until then, the Spanish government knew virtually nothing about ETA logistics {{Citation needed|date=September 2016}} and this operation was an important turning point.
Judge [[Baltasar Garzón]] issued a warrant of arrest for Francisco Paesa on December 1, 1988 for collaboration with armed band and use of false identities.
===Roldán=== [[Luis Roldán]], known for being the Director General of the Spanish Civil Guard when a big scandal of corruption arose in 1993, have said that Paesa tricked him into stealing all the money that Roldán had previously stolen in that case<ref>[http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/2014-05-19/paesa-se-quedo-con-todo-el-dinero-y-ademas-el-ministro-belloch-le-pago-1-8-millones_131783/ Paesa se quedó con todo el dinero y además el ministro Belloch le pagó 1,8 millones"] in elconfidencial.com</ref> but the judicial case on the research to hide the heritage of Luis Roldán was filed in 2004, as the crime had prescribed.
===Alleged death and later years=== In 1998 he faked a fatal cardiac arrest in Thailand. Obituaries were published<ref>[http://estaticos02.cache.el-mundo.net/documentos/2004/11/15/esquela.jpg Obituary of Francisco Paesa]</ref> and a death certificate was forged. His family even commissioned thirty [[Gregorian Masses]] for his soul. The Spanish authorities believed that he had faked his death and he had escaped with two billion pesetas (given to him by Roldán).
He reappeared on Spanish media in 2004. He was mentioned as an organizer of an operation to overthrow [[Equatorial Guinea]] dictator [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo|Obiang]] with an army of mercenaries. Some say that Francisco Paesa was spotted by a detective agency in Barcelona, others in France and some in Luxembourg. However, everyone agreed that he had an Argentine passport with the name Francisco Pando Sánchez.
In December 2005, the magazine ''[[Interviú]]'' surprised him in Paris, where he was interviewed by director {{Interlanguage link multi|Manuel Cerdán|es}}. He was 68 years old and his figure was impeccable. He explained that "his death" had been a misunderstanding, since it was reported that he was one of the three people who died in a shooting in [[Bangkok]]. He was willing to show the scars. As for the Russian mafia, he asked journalists to not publish the photos because that would force him to commit suicide.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/european_football/article746090.ece G. Keely en Timesonline]</ref>
In September 2016, the magazine ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' published an exclusive interview with Paesa. According to Paesa, his supposed death in Thailand was a misunderstanding; he was on an Anti-Terrorism commission from the Argentine Government when he was shot, wounded in action and taken to an unknown boat where he spent 7 months in a coma.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.revistavanityfair.es/la-revista/articulos/entrevista-espia-francisco-paesa-vanity-fair/22845|title=Entrevistamos en exclusiva a Paesa, el espía más oscuro y famoso de España|date=2016-09-15|newspaper=Vanity Fair|access-date=2017-02-11|language=es}}</ref>
==In fiction== The 2016 Spanish film ''[[Smoke & Mirrors (2016 film)|Smoke & Mirrors]]'' is based on his life.<ref>[http://www.europapress.es/andalucia/cultura-00621/noticia-hombre-mil-caras-nueva-pelicula-alberto-rodriguez-encuentra-pleno-rodaje-madrid-20150811170024.html Europapress 11/08/2015]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:Hans Willem, baron van Aylva (1635-91). Generaal-majoor, genoemd 'de ontzaglijke generaal' Rijksmuseum SK-A-1401.jpeg|thumb|270px|Hans Willem van Aylva]] '''Hans Willem van Aylva''' (ca. 1633, [[Holwerd]] - 21 February 1691, near [[Leuven]]) was a Dutch soldier.
In 1667 he participated in the Dutch [[Raid on Medway]]. He was appointed a [[Major General]] in 1668 and promoted to [[Lieutenant General]] four years later.<ref>Childs p.344</ref> He was also [[Lieutenant Admiral]] of [[Friesland]]. He saw a great deal of service in the [[Franco-Dutch War]] during the 1670s, and was badly wounded at the [[Battle of Seneffe]] in 1674.
Following the outbreak of the [[Nine Years War]] he commanded a small Dutch army that took part in early operations around [[Cologne]] where he co-operated with German forces under [[Hans Adam von Schöning]].<ref>Childs p.103</ref> At the [[Battle of Walcourt]] (1689) he led a mixed force of English and Dutch soldiers. In 1690 he arrived just too late to fight at the [[Battle of Fleurus (1690)|Battle of Fleurus]], but his troops were able to allow [[Prince Georg Friedrich of Waldeck|Waldeck]]'s defeated Allied army to retreat safely.<ref>Childs p.145</ref>
The following year he died after falling from his horse.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * Childs, John. ''The Nine Years' War and the British Army, 1688-97''. Manchester University Press, 1991.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aylva, Hans Willem van}} [[Category:1633 births]] [[Category:1691 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century Dutch military personnel]] [[Category:Admirals of the navy of the Dutch Republic]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Dutch generals]] <!-- [[Category:Dutch military personnel of the Franco-Dutch War]] There is no Franco-Dutch War category yet, let-alone subcategories. I trust they will show up sometimes.--> [[Category:Dutch military personnel of the Nine Years' War]] [[Category:People from Dongeradeel]]

revision.comment: /* Introduction */ Priority of helicase dependent amplification is currently misleading.
revision.text:
'''Helicase-dependent amplification''' (HDA) is a method for ''[[in vitro]]'' [[DNA]] amplification (like the [[polymerase chain reaction]]) that takes place at a constant temperature.
==Introduction== The polymerase chain reaction is the most widely used method for ''in vitro'' DNA amplification for purposes of molecular biology and biomedical research.<ref>{{cite journal | journal=Science | volume=239 | issue=4839 | pages=487–491 | year=1988 |vauthors=Saiki RK, etal | title=Primer-directed enzymatic amplification of DNA with a thermostable DNA polymerase | pmid=2448875 | doi = 10.1126/science.2448875 }}</ref> This process involves the separation of the double-stranded DNA in high heat into single strands (the denaturation step, typically achieved at 95–97 °C), annealing of the primers to the single stranded DNA (the annealing step) and copying the single strands to create new double-stranded DNA (the extension step that requires the DNA polymerase) requires the reaction to be done in a [[thermal cycler]]. These bench-top machines are large, expensive and costly to run and maintain, limiting the potential applications of DNA amplification in situations outside the laboratory (e.g., in the identification of potentially hazardous micro-organisms at the scene of investigation, or at the point of care of a patient). Although PCR is usually associated with thermal cycling, the original patent by Mullis et al. <ref>{{cite patent | patent= U.S. Patent No. 4,683,195,}}</ref> disclosed the use of a helicase as a means for denaturation of double stranded DNA thereby including isothermal nucleic acid amplification. ''In vivo'', DNA is replicated by DNA polymerases with various accessory proteins, including a DNA helicase that acts to separate the DNA by unwinding the DNA double helix.<ref>{{cite book |vauthors=Kornberg A, Baker T | year=1992 | title=DNA Replication, 2nd edn| publisher=WH Freeman and Company: New York | isbn=978-1-891389-44-3}}</ref> HDA was developed from this concept, using a [[helicase]] (an [[enzyme]]) to denature the DNA.
== Methodology ==
Strands of double stranded DNA are first separated by a DNA helicase and coated by single stranded DNA (ssDNA)-binding proteins. In the second step, two sequence specific primers hybridise to each border of the DNA template. DNA polymerases are then used to extend the primers annealed to the templates to produce a double stranded DNA and the two newly synthesized DNA products are then used as substrates by DNA helicases, entering the next round of the reaction. Thus, a simultaneous chain reaction develops, resulting in exponential amplification of the selected target sequence (see Vincent ''et al.''., 2004<ref>{{cite journal | journal=EMBO Rep | volume=5 | issue=8 | pages=795–800 | year=2004 |vauthors=Vincent M, Xu Y, Kong H | title=Helicase-dependent isothermal DNA amplification | pmid=15247927 | doi = 10.1038/sj.embor.7400200 | pmc=1249482}}</ref> for a schematic diagram).
== Present progress and the advantages and disadvantages of HDA ==
Since the publication of its discovery, HDA technology is being used for a "simple, easy to adapt nucleic acid test for the detection of ''Clostridium difficile''".<ref>{{cite journal|journal=J Mol Diagn |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=452–8 |year=2008 |vauthors=Chow WH, McCloskey C, Tong Y, Hu L, You Q, Kelly CP, Kong H, Tang YW, Tang W |title=Application of isothermal helicase-dependent amplification with a disposable detection device in a simple sensitive stool test for toxigenic Clostridium difficile |url=http://jmd.amjpathol.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18669881 |pmid=18669881 |doi=10.2353/jmoldx.2008.080008 |pmc=2518740 }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Other applications include the rapid detection of ''Staphylococcus aureus '' by the amplification and detection of a short DNA sequence specific to the bacterium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biohelix.com/products/IsoAmp_Staph_Kit.asp |publisher=Biohelix corp. |title=IsoAmp Rapid Staph Detection Kit (product description) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010074519/http://www.biohelix.com/products/IsoAmp_Staph_Kit.asp |archivedate=2009-10-10 |df= }}</ref> The advantages of HDA is that it provides a rapid method of nucleic acid amplification of a specific target at an isothermic temperature that does not require a thermal cycler. However, the optimisation of primers and sometimes buffers is required beforehand by the researcher. Normally primer and buffer optimisation is tested and achieved through PCR, raising the question of the need to spend extra on a separate system to do the actual amplification. Despite the selling point that HDA negates the use of a thermal cycler and therefore allows research to be conducted in the field, much of the work required to detect potentially hazardous microorganisms is carried out in a research/hospital lab setting regardless. At present, mass diagnoses from a great number of samples cannot yet be achieved by HDA, whereas PCR reactions carried out in [[thermal cycler]] that can hold multi-well sample plates allows for the amplification and detection of the intended DNA target from a maximum of 96 samples. The cost of purchasing reagents for HDA are also relatively expensive to that of PCR reagents, more so since it comes as a ready-made kit.
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.biohelix.com|Biohelix Corporation official website}}
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Helicase-Dependent Amplification}} [[Category:Molecular biology techniques]] [[Category:Laboratory techniques]] [[Category:Amplifiers]] [[Category:Biotechnology]]

{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=I-68.jpg |Ship image size=250px |Ship caption=The ''I-68'' in March 1934. }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=[[Empire of Japan]] |Ship flag=[[Image:Naval Ensign of Japan.svg|60px]] |Ship name=I-168 |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=Kure Dockyard |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=26 June 1933<ref name="Jentschura" /> |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= Kure Dock Yard on July 31, 1934 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate= sunk on 27 July 1943 by USS Scamp (SS-277)|USS ''Scamp'']] |Ship status= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=KD6 Type, [[Kaidai class submarine|Kaidai class]] |Ship displacement=1400 (1785 maximum) tons surface, 2440 tons submerged<ref name="Jentschura" /> |Ship length=322' 10" |Ship beam=26' 11" |Ship draught=15' |Ship draft= |Ship propulsion=Twin shaft Kampon 9000 horse-power/two stroke diesels bhp |Ship speed=23 knots diesel/8.2 knots electric<ref name="Jentschura">Jentschura p. 172</ref> |Ship range=14,000 nautical miles<ref name="Jentschura" /> |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth=230' |Ship complement=60-84 officers and men |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*6 x [[torpedo tube]]s/14 21" [[torpedo]]es *1 x 4" AA Gun *1 X [[Hotchkiss M1929 machine gun|{{convert|13.2|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] AA Gun |Ship notes= }} |} The '''Japanese submarine ''I-168''''' ('''''I-68''''', until 20 May 1942) was a [[Kaidai type submarine|''Kaidai'' type]] of [[cruiser submarine]] active in [[World War II]].<ref name="Jentschura"/> A KD6 [[ship class|sub-class]] boat, ''I-168'' was built for the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] (IJN) in the early 1930s. At the [[Battle of Midway]] she sank the only [[United States Navy|American]] warships lost in the battle: the [[aircraft carrier]] {{USS|Yorktown|CV-5}} and the [[destroyer]] {{USS|Hammann|DD-412}}. At that time she was commanded by Lieutenant Commander Yahachi Tanabe.
==Early career== The submarine was completed at the Kure Dock Yard on 31 July 1934. She was originally designated ''I-68''. On 23 November 1941, ''I-68'' and the rest of Submarine Squadron 3 were stationed near [[Hawaii]] to perform reconnaissance duties in preparation for the impending [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]. Still on station near Hawaii on December 13, ''I-68'' was subjected to 21 separate depth charge attacks. The last attack damaged her batteries and flooded the aft torpedo tubes. After undergoing repairs at [[Kwajalein]], ''I-68'' conducted several uneventful patrols in the Pacific, before being redesignated ''I-168'' on 20 May 1942 as part of a general submarine re-numbering program undertaken by the IJN.
==Battle of Midway== ''I-168'' was one of 13 submarines forming the Advance Expeditionary Force of the Japanese attack on Midway. Under the command of Tanabe Yahachi, she steamed south of Midway as far as Kure Island during her approach on 31 May 1942. The American aircraft carriers had passed through the area of the submarine patrol line before the submarines arrived on their patrol stations. ''I-168'' spent the first three days of June observing Midway's southern horizon through the periscope by day and through binoculars at a range of five miles at night. ''I-168'' observed and reported heavy aircraft activity indicating the island anticipated the Japanese attack. She made periscope observations during the first Japanese air attack on Midway. ''I-168'' commenced shelling Midway with its 10-cm (4-inch) deck gun at 0130 5 June; but submerged when illuminated by shore searchlights after firing only 6 rounds.<ref>Tanabe, May 1963, pp.60-61</ref>
''I-168'' was unsuccessfully attacked by aircraft on 5 June; and upon surfacing after the attack, received orders to sink the damaged American aircraft carrier USS ''Yorktown''. Lookouts detected ''Yorktown'', and the destroyer ''Hammann'' alongside her at 0530 6 June. ''I-168'' closed the range from 11 miles at six knots, and then slowed to three knots for the final approach through ''Yorktown'''s destroyer screen. Over-cautious use of the periscope resulted in getting too close to the carrier on the initial approach, so the submarine circled to starboard to increase the range and then fired a salvo of four torpedoes at 1330 from a range of 1200 yards. After observing the torpedo hits, ''I-168'' descended to 200 feet and slowed to three knots directly under ''Yorktown''. American destroyers ''[[USS Gwin (DD-433)|Gwin]]'', ''[[USS Hughes (DD-410)|Hughes]]'', and ''[[USS Monaghan (DD-354)|Monaghan]]'' dropped 60 depth charges before damaging ''I-168'' at 1530. A depth charge exploding near the bow put out the lights, damaged the forward battery room, sprung the hatches to No. 1 torpedo tube and reduced the submerged depth to 60 feet. All unoccupied crewmen grabbed sacks of rice from forward storage and moved astern to trim the submarine because of the flooding forward. After a few hours of relative quiet, ''I-168'' surfaced an hour before sunset and ran west at 14 knots to charge batteries and ventilate interior spaces. Two American destroyers spotted her at a range of 11000 yards and commenced firing from a range of 6500 yards about 30 minutes later. ''I-168'' submerged and evaded the approaching destroyers.<ref>Tanabe, May 1963, pp.59-65</ref>
After conducting emergency repairs, Tanabe and his crew limped back to [[Japan]] using only two engines, a journey of twelve days. Following full repairs at [[Sasebo, Nagasaki|Sasebo]], ''I-168'' was placed under the command of Lieutenant Commander Katsuji Watanabe and reassigned to cargo transportation missions to the beleaguered [[Solomon Islands]] and [[Kiska]].{{citation needed|date=June 2012}}
==Fate== On 27 July 1943, ''I-168'' engaged the American submarine [[USS Scamp (SS-277)|USS ''Scamp'']] in the [[Steffen Strait]] near [[New Hanover Island]]. After crash-diving his boat under an incoming torpedo, Lieutenant Commander Walter Gale Ebert returned fire, sinking ''I-168'' with all hands.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * {{cite book|author=Jentschura|first=Hansgeorg|author2=Dieter Jung |author3=Peter Mickel |title=Warships of the Imperial Japanese Navy, 1869-1945|publisher=United States Naval Institute|location=Annapolis, Maryland, USA|year=1977|isbn=0-87021-893-X}} * {{cite journal|author=Tanabe, Yahachi |title=I sank the ''Yorktown'' at Midway |publisher=United States Naval Institute [[Proceedings]] magazine. |date=May 1963}} * Tabular record of movement at [http://www.combinedfleet.com/I-168.htm]
==External links== * [https://www.navegar-es-preciso.com/news/el-sumergible-japones-i-68-renombrado-i-168-o-el-submarino-hundido-por-otro-submarino/ El sumergible japonés I-68 (spanish)]

[[File:Katrina_Spade_Headshot_2017.jpg|thumb|Katrina Spade stands in front of a mossy tree in Seattle, WA in 2017.]] '''Katrina Mogielnicki Spade''' (born September 9, 1977{{Cite web|url=https://crosscut.com/2017/09/death-industry-seattle-alternative-aquamation-caitlin-doughty|title=Seattle, you've got a new moniker: 'death-positive'|website=crosscut.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}) is an American [[designer]], [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]], and [[death care]] advocate.{{Cite news|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members|title=Order Members {{!}} The Order of the Good Death|work=The Order of the Good Death|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en-US}} Spade is the founder of Recompose, a [[public-benefit corporation]] developing a natural alternative to conventional [[cremation]] and [[burial]]. She was awarded the [[Echoing Green]] Climate Fellowship in 2014 for her work.{{Cite web|url=https://www.echoinggreen.org/fellows/katrina-spade|title=Katrina Spade {{!}} Echoing Green|website=www.echoinggreen.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}} == Early life and education == Spade grew up in rural [[New Hampshire]] and was raised by a physician and physician's assistant.{{Cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/life/from-corpse-to-compost-the-urban-death-projects-modest-proposal/|title=Seattle could get an Urban Death Project human composter in just 7 years|date=2016-10-28|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en-US}} She told the [[The Stranger (newspaper)|Seattle ''Stranger'']] of that time in her life, "We weren't religious, but we saw nature as somehow spiritual."{{Cite news |url=https://www.thestranger.com/features/feature/2015/03/03/21792773/the-architect-who-wants-to-redesign-being-dead|title=The Architect Who Wants to Redesign Being Dead|work=The Stranger|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}} She earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[anthropology]] from [[Haverford College]] in Pennsylvania, then turned her focus to [[sustainable design]] while attending Yestermorrow Design/Build School in [[Vermont]]. At Yestermorrow, Spade helped to build a Pain Mound - a [[compost]]-based [[bioenergy]] system invented by [[Jean Pain]] that can produce heat for up to 18 months.{{Cite news |url=http://www.instructables.com/id/Compost-Heating-System/|title=Compost Heating System |work=Instructables.com|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}} Later, while earning a [[Master of Architecture]] from the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]], she wrote a [[thesis]] entitled "A Place for the Urban Dead", an idea for which she was awarded the [[Echoing Green]] Climate Fellowship in 2014. == Urban Death Project == {{Main|Urban Death Project}} In considering her own mortality, Spade wanted options more that were environmentally sustainable and allowed family and friends to participate in the care of their loved one.{{Cite news|url=http://www.metropolismag.com/cities/the-urban-death-project-bringing-death-back-into-the-urban-realm/|title=The Urban Death Project: Bringing Death Back Into the Urban Realm|date=2017-02-24|work=Metropolis|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en-US}} She formulated early ideas about the possibility of human recomposition, but when she learned about the practice of livestock mortality [[compost]]ing, she began work to create the same option for humans. Spade founded the [[Urban Death Project]] in 2014 with a focus on developing a new system of death care called recomposition, which transforms human bodies into soil.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/2016/10/inside-machine-will-turn-corpse-compost/ |title=Inside the Machine That Will Turn Your Corpse Into Compost |work=WIRED |access-date=2018-06-13 |language=en-US}} The system is not yet recognized as a legal form of disposition in the United States. == Recompose == In 2018, the Urban Death Project dissolved and Spade founded Recompose, a public-benefit corporation. Similar to the Urban Death Project, Recompose is developing a [[patent pending]] process that converts human remains to soil.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/recompose-and-the-conservation-burial-movement|title=The Last Thing We Ever Do Is Unsustainable. This Woman Wants To Change That|date=2018-04-03|work=mindbodygreen|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}} It seeks to create a scalable and sustainable alternative to natural burial, particularly for urban dwellers. == Advocacy and awards == * Awarded [[Ashoka (non-profit organization)|Ashoka]] Fellowship, October 2018{{Cite news|url=https://www.ashoka.org/en/fellow/katrina-spade|title=Katrina Spade|work=Ashoka {{!}} Everyone a Changemaker|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en}} * SVP Social Venture Partners Fast Pitch 1st Place and Audience Choice Award, 2016{{Cite web|url=http://www.socialventurepartners.org/seattle/news/big-applause-svp-fast-pitch-2016-winners/|title=SVP Seattle Congratulations SVP Fast Pitch 2016 Winners! - SVP Seattle|website=www.socialventurepartners.org|access-date=2018-06-13}} * [[Buckminster Fuller]] Prize Semifinalist, 2016 - Designs That Are Changing the World{{Cite news|url=https://inhabitat.com/8-groundbreaking-buckminster-fuller-semifinalist-designs-that-are-changing-the-world/|title=8 groundbreaking Buckminster Fuller semifinalist designs that are changing the world|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en-US}} *Awarded [[Echoing Green]] Climate Fellowship, 2014 *[[TED (conference)|TED]] Speaker: When I Die, Recompose Me{{Cite news|url=https://www.ted.com/speakers/katrina_spade|title=Katrina Spade {{!}} Speaker {{!}} TED|last=Spade|first=Katrina|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}} * Member of "[[The Order of the Good Death]]", an "inclusive community of funeral industry professionals, academics, as well as artists who advocate for and make possible, a more death informed society."{{Citation|title=Caitlin Doughty|date=2018-06-13|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Caitlin_Doughty&oldid=845625570|encyclopedia=Wikipedia|language=en|accessdate=2018-06-13}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/09/13/348223758/a-cheerful-mortician-tackles-the-lighter-side-of-death|title=A Cheerful Mortician Tackles The Lighter Side Of Death|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.recompose.life Recompose official website] {{improve categories|date=July 2018}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Spade, Katrina}} [[Category:People from New Hampshire]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Persons involved with death and dying]] [[Category:Women and death]] [[Category:Social entrepreneurs]]

{{Refimprove|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox comics species |image = |imagesize = |caption = |publisher = [[Wildstorm Comics]] |debut = ''[[Wildcats (comics)|WildC.A.T.S.]]'' #1 |debutmo = August |debutyr = 1992 |creators = [[Brandon Choi]]
[[Jim Lee]] |deities = |homeworld = Khera |members = [[Mister Majestic]] |powers = semi-immortality, enhanced physicality , various powers by subspecies |subcat = |altcat = |alttop = y |sortkey = Kherubim }} The '''Kherubim''' or Kherans are an [[List of extraterrestrials in fiction|alien race]] in the [[fiction]]al [[Wildstorm Universe]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/24114-wildstorm-vets-reunite-for-oral-history.html |title=WILDSTORM Vets Reunite For Oral History |publisher=[[Newsarama.com]] |date=2015-04-13 |accessdate=2015-10-29}} They were created by [[Jim Lee]] and first appeared in ''[[Wildcats (comics)|WildC.A.Ts]]'' #1 (August 1992). ==Biology== Kherubim are various groups/races of people from the planet Khera. Kherubim resemble humans in appearance but are physically far stronger and more durable and extremely long-lived, nearly [[Immortality|immortal]]. [[Savant (Wildstorm)|Savant]] was harmed by armor-piercing machine gun bullets; however, after they are surgically removed, she makes a full and rapid recovery. Kherans (including Titanthropes) can interbreed with humans, bearing fertile offspring. An evolutionary drawback to their near-immortality is that nearly all Kheran females are [[infertile]]; only very rarely will a Kheran produce offspring. This is a natural check against overpopulation. Only one in 10,000 Kheran females is capable of giving birth, and only then at her very first mating. Of those, only one in approximately 10,000 will become pregnant, and only 1 in 1000 of those babies will be born alive; the rest are stillborn. The saving grace of the species is that this infertility does not seem to apply when the Kheran is mating with another species, as Earth has various Kheran/human hybrids. More powerful Kherans are known as Lords and may possess telekinetic and energy manipulation abilities. [[Mister Majestic]], [[Lord Emp]] and [[Spartan (comics)|Yohn Khol]] are Kherubim Lords. Shapers are a [[subspecies]] of Kherans. They are [[shapeshifters]] who are able to manipulate the molecular structure of their bodies, transforming part or all of their bodies into a substance with [[metal]]lic properties, which they can manipulate and reshape at will. The Wildcat [[Warblade (comics)|Warblade]] is a Shaper. Though genetically a different species, the Titanthropes (or simply Titans) have been part of Kherubim society for so long that they are also often called Kherubim. However, they are considered and treated as second-class citizens of Khera by the Kherubim. They are large, purple-skinned humanoids who are able to increase or decrease their mass. Males have large yellow horns growing from their backs. A Titan's intelligence is inversely proportional to their current size. The Wildcat [[Maul (Wildstorm)|Maul]] is a Titanthrope. ==History== Thousands of years ago, the Kherubim destroyed their own planet, according to Titan myth. They then came to Khera and settled it, subjugating the Titans. The Titans would slowly become more or less accepted within the Kherubim society but remained [[second-class citizen]]s. Millennia ago, the Kherans came into contact with the [[Daemonite]]s and a war erupted between both species. This war would last several centuries. A small group of Kherans and Daemonites crashlanded on Earth and inspired humanity with tales of gods, angels, demons, and monsters. Their conflict would continue until the end of the 20th century, while in space the Kherans would go on to defeat the Daemonites. Kherans imposed heavy [[indemnity|indemnities]] on the Daemonites and their society went bankrupt trying to pay them off. Khera allowed Daemonites to migrate to the more prosperous planet, but forced these Daemonites refugees to live in [[ghetto]]s. When a small group of Kheran and half-Kheran heroes from Earth known as the [[Wildcats (comics)|WildC.A.Ts]] arrived on Khera, they were welcomed as heroes, but quickly learned that Kheran society had changed over the years. Disgusted with the autocratic nature of Kheran society, they left the planet and returned to Earth. Later, the Kherubim lord [[Mister Majestic|Majestros]] found hidden Kheran devices, known as Planet Shaper Engines, beneath the surface of the Earth. This caused the realization that humanity and Kherans were closely related and that similar species had been seeded throughout the universe, creating both the Daemonites and Kherans in addition to humans. The Shaper Guild from Khera arrived on Earth and announced that factions within Kherubim society had decided on using Planet Shaper Engines to transform the Earth into another Khera, causing a civil war. ==Culture== Kherans are a warrior race with a strong emphasis on hand-to-hand combat and [[honor]]. Due to their low fertility, every Kheran man and woman coming of age has to mate with an appointed partner. If the woman gives birth, she must become a priestess. If not, she may go on to live her life as she wishes. [[Zealot (Wildstorm)|Lady Zannah]] has managed to avoid becoming a priestess, despite giving birth, because her mother told others that the baby had died, allowing Zannah to become a warrior. Her mother then passed Zannah's baby, [[Savant (Wildstorm)|Kenesha]], off as Zealot's sister. As a mother of two children, Zannah's mother, Harmony, has become a living legend. No Kheran can remember the last time a Kheran woman gave birth to more than one child in her life. Zannah became the founder of the [[Coda (Wildstorm)|Coda]] Sisterhood. Older and more powerful Kherans are named Lords. It remains unclear what makes a Kheran a Lord, but a Lord is capable of undergoing the ritual of Ascension when he is ready. The Ascension ritual is an important part of the Kheran culture, where a Lord asks a partner or good friend to destroy his body so that his spirit can be free. A Lord usually has so much energy stored in his body that this process tends to consume both Kherans. The Coda worship a goddess, Hecate, but little is known about this religion. Other Kherans apparently do not worship any gods but believe in individual enlightenment through Ascension. Though originally seen as noble and protective of other species, the Kherans were later shown to be quite [[speciesism|speciesist]], looking down upon other species while perceiving themselves as tolerant and benevolent. ==Politics== The Kherans have a political system where various parties vie for power. The various factions include: *The Pantheon, the party of the Lords. They are currently in power and stand for stability and economic progress. *The Coda, a sisterhood of warriors. They want war and combat to prove their worth. *The Shapers Guild represents all Shapers within Kheran society. They follow the orders from the Pantheon but have their own secret agenda. They claim to shape the destiny of Khera and are aware of its true origin. *The Titantropes, while individually repressed by the Kherubim, hold great power as a faction. While being only a small political faction, it is in fact their vote that either keeps the Pantheon in power or puts the Coda in power. * The Brotherhood of the Sword: a male version of the Coda, its members are created through [[genetic engineering]] and [[cloning]]. They devote their whole life to the mastery of bladed weapons and suppressing their own emotions. Some Bladesmen sacrifice themselves to become Scimitars, using stolen DNA from the Shapers Guild to become living war machines. The Brotherhood on Earth betrayed Khera and allied themselves with the Daemonites. * The Adrastea: a race of Kherubim empaths, originally bred to be slaves, but they soon became the largest [[organized crime|crime syndicate]] in Kheran society. ==Technology== While preferring bladed weapons in combat, Kherans are technologically advanced. They own spaceships capable of interstellar flights. They are capable of inscribing knowledge in the form of organic molecules, which when injected into the bloodstream, downloads that knowledge straight into the brain. They are capable of manipulating the laws of chance, simply for the purpose of entertainment as their 'Coincidental Mansion' shows. Armies of very advanced [[Android (robot)|androids]] known as the [[Spartan (comics)|Spartan Guards]] serve as soldiers. Spartan Guards have shown high intelligence and superhuman physical capabilities. Kherubim Planet Shapers can [[Terraforming|terraform]] worlds and alter living DNA and can remain functional for billions of years. ==Notable Kherans== *[[Mister Majestic|Lord Majestros]], the greatest living hero for all Kherubim. *[[Lord Emp]], ascended from the physical plane. Former member of the Pantheon. *[[Zealot (Wildstorm)|Lady Zannah]], former member of the Coda. *[[Savant (Wildstorm)|Kenesha]] *[[Spartan (comics)|Lord Yohn Kohl]], the template for the android Spartan. *Lord S'lyton, father of [[Backlash (Marc Slayton)|Marc Slayton]] *Ferrian, member of [[Wildcore]]. *Charis, also known as [[Nemesis (Wildstorm)|Nemesis]]. An Adrastea with empathic abilities, trained by the Coda. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{WildCATs}} [[Category:Fictional extraterrestrial life forms]] [[Category:Fictional shapeshifters]] [[Category:Fictional warrior races]] [[Category:WildCats characters]]

{{Use American English|date=January 2018}} The '''Kübler-Ross model''' is popularly known as the '''five stages of grief,''' though more accurately, the model postulates a progression of emotional states experienced by terminally ill patients after diagnosis. The five stages are chronologically: [[denial]], [[anger]], [[Bargaining (psychology)|bargaining]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and [[acceptance]]. The model was first introduced by Swiss-American psychiatrist [[Elisabeth Kübler-Ross]] in her 1969 book ''[[On Death and Dying]]'', and was inspired by her work with [[Terminal illness|terminally ill]] patients.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,689491,00.html |title= Milestones |date=August 30, 2004 | publisher=TIME | first=Sarah M. | last=Broom}} Motivated by the lack of instruction in medical schools on the subject of death and dying, Kübler-Ross examined death and those faced with it at the [[University of Chicago]] medical school. Kübler-Ross' project evolved into a series of seminars which, along with patient interviews and previous research, became the foundation for her book.{{cite web |url=http://www.uky.edu/~cperring/kr.htm |title=PHI350: The Stages in the Dying Process |first=Christian |last=Perring |access-date=November 27, 2016}} Although Kübler-Ross is commonly credited with creating stage models, earlier bereavement theorists and clinicians such as [[Erich Lindemann]], [[Colin Murray Parkes|Collin Murray Parkes]], and [[John Bowlby]] used similar models of stages of phases as early as the 1940s.{{Cite book |title=Bereavement groups and the role of social support : integrating theory, research, and practice |last=Hoy |first=William G. |date=2016 |publisher=Routledge/Taylor and Francis |isbn=9781317416357 |location=New York |oclc=942843686}} Later in her life, Kübler-Ross noted that the stages are not a linear and predictable progression and that she regretted writing them in a way that was misunderstood. "Kübler-Ross originally saw these stages as reflecting how people cope with illness and dying," observed grief researcher Kenneth J. Doka, "not as reflections of how people grieve."Doka, Kenneth J., ''Grief Is a Journey: Finding Your Path Through Loss'' (Simon and Schuster, 2016): 6. == Stages of dying in terminal illness == The stages, popularly known by the acronym '''DABDA''', include:{{cite book |title=A Topical Approach to Life-Span Development |last= Santrock |first=J.W. |authorlink= |year= 2007 |publisher= [[McGraw-Hill]] |location= New York |isbn= 0-07-338264-7 |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}{{page needed|date=May 2014}} # '''[[Denial]]''' – The first reaction is denial. In this stage, individuals believe the diagnosis is somehow mistaken, and cling to a false, preferable reality. # '''[[Anger]]''' – When the individual recognizes that denial cannot continue, they become frustrated, especially at proximate individuals. Certain psychological responses of a person undergoing this phase would be: "Why me? It's not fair!"; "How can this happen to me?"; "Who is to blame?"; "Why would this happen?". # '''[[Bargaining]]''' – The third stage involves the hope that the individual can avoid a cause of grief. Usually, the negotiation for an extended life is made in exchange for a reformed lifestyle. People facing less serious trauma can bargain or seek compromise. Examples include the terminally ill person who "negotiates with God" to attend a daughter's wedding or an attempt to bargain for more time to live in exchange for a reformed lifestyle. # '''[[Depression (mood)|Depression]]''' – "I'm so sad, why bother with anything?"; "I'm going to die soon, so what's the point?"; "I miss my loved one; why go on?"
During the fourth stage, the individual despairs at the recognition of their mortality. In this state, the individual may become silent, refuse visitors and spend much of the time mournful and sullen. # '''[[Acceptance]]''' – "It's going to be okay."; "I can't fight it; I may as well prepare for it."
In this last stage, individuals embrace mortality or inevitable future, or that of a loved one, or other tragic event. People dying may precede the survivors in this state, which typically comes with a calm, retrospective view for the individual, and a stable condition of emotions. In a book co-authored with David Kessler and published posthumously, Kübler-Ross expanded her model to include any form of personal loss, such as the death of a loved one, the loss of a job or income, major [[Social rejection|rejection]], the end of a relationship or [[divorce]], [[drug addiction]], [[incarceration]], the onset of a [[disease]] or an [[infertility]] diagnosis, and even minor losses, such as a loss of insurance coverage.{{Cite book |title=On grief & grieving : finding the meaning of grief through the five stages of loss |last=Kübler-Ross |first=Elisabeth |date=2014 |publisher=Scribner |last2=Kessler |first2=David |isbn=9781476775555 |location=New York |oclc=863077888}} [[File:Kübler Ross grieving curve.png|thumb|A diagram developed by Bertrand GRONDIN from a presentation of Elisabeth Kübler Ross ideas produced by [[France Telecom]]]] [[File:Kübler Ross's stages of grief.png|thumb|Diagram showing two possible outcomes of grief or a life-changing event developed for [[Jobcentre Plus]] by Eos]] ==Criticism== Criticisms of this five-stage model of grief center mainly on a lack of [[empirical research]] and [[empirical evidence]] supporting the stages as described by Kübler-Ross and, to the contrary, empirical support for other modes of the expression of grief. Moreover, Kübler-Ross' model is the product of a particular culture at a particular time and might not be applicable to people of other cultures. These points have been made by many experts, [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0030222817691870] such as Professor Robert J. Kastenbaum (1932–2013) who was a recognized expert in gerontology, aging, and death. In his writings, Kastenbaum raised the following points:Kastenbaum, Robert. ''Death, Society, and Human Experience'', 6th edition. Boston: Allyn & Bacon, 1998.Corr, Charles A., Kenneth J. Doka, and Robert Kastenbaum (1999). "Dying and Its Interpreters: A Review of Selected Literature and Some Comments on the State of the Field." ''Omega: The Journal of Death and Dying'' '''39'''(4) :239–259. doi.org/10.2190/3KGF-52BV-QTNT-UBMX * The existence of these stages as such has not been demonstrated. * No evidence has been presented that people actually do move from Stage 1 through Stage 5. * The limitations of the method have not been acknowledged. * The line is blurred between description and prescription. * The resources, pressures, and characteristics of the immediate environment, which can make a tremendous difference, are not taken into account. A 2003 study of bereaved individuals conducted by Maciejewski and colleagues at [[Yale University]] obtained some findings consistent with the five-stage hypothesis but others inconsistent with it. Several letters were also published in the same journal criticizing this research and arguing against the stage idea.{{cite journal |last1=Maciejewski |first1=Paul K. |last2=Zhang |first2=Baohui |last3=Block |first3=Susan D. |last4=Prigerson |first4=Holly G. |year=2007 |title=An Empirical Examination of the Stage Theory of Grief |journal=Journal of the American Medical Association |volume=297 |issue=7 |pages=716–23 |pmid=17312291 |doi=10.1001/jama.297.7.716}} [[George Bonanno]], Professor of Clinical Psychology at Columbia University, in his book ''The Other Side of Sadness: What the New Science of Bereavement Tells Us About Life After a Loss'',{{cite book|last=Bonanno|first=George|authorlink=George Bonanno|title=The Other Side of Sadness: What the New Science of Bereavement Tells Us about Life After Loss|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HLXuAAAAMAAJ|year=2009|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-465-01360-9}} summarizes [[peer-review]]ed research based on thousands of subjects over two decades and concludes that a natural [[psychological resilience]] is a principal component of grief{{cite journal |last1=Bonanno |first1=George A. |title=Loss, trauma, and human resilience: have we underestimated the human capacity to thrive after extremely aversive events? |journal=The American Psychologist |volume=59 |issue=1 |pages=20–8 |date=January 2004 |pmid=14736317 |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.59.1.20}} and that there are no stages of grief to pass. Bonanno's work has also demonstrated that absence of grief or trauma symptoms is a healthy outcome.{{cite web|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=the-neuroscience-of-true-grit |title=The Neuroscience of True Grit |doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0311-28 |publisher=[[Scientific American]] |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2016-12-29}} The lack of support in peer-reviewed research or objective clinical observation by many practitioners in the field has led to the labels of ''myth'' and ''fallacy'' in the notion that there are stages of grief.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2042372-2,00.html|title=New Ways to Think About Grief|first=Ruth Davis|last=Konigsberg|date=January 29, 2011|publisher=|access-date=November 27, 2016|via=www.time.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/five-fallacies-of-grief/ |title=Five Fallacies of Grief: Debunking Psychological Stages |publisher=[[Scientific American]] |date=2008-11-01 |accessdate=2016-12-29}} Nevertheless, the model's use has persisted in popular news and entertainment media including the animated sitcom ''The Simpsons''.{{Citation|last=Liam Dominic Fanning|title=The Simpsons: Five Stages of Grief|date=2017-09-09|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=ohrjV8hBmC0|access-date=2018-08-02}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Kübler-Ross, E. (1969) ''On Death and Dying'', Routledge, {{ISBN|0-415-04015-9}} * Kübler-Ross, E. (2005) ''On Grief and Grieving: Finding the Meaning of Grief Through the Five Stages of Loss'', Simon & Schuster Ltd, {{ISBN|0-7432-6344-8}} * Scire, P. (2007). "Applying Grief Stages to Organizational Change" * ''An Attributional Analysis of Kübler-Ross' Model of Dying'', Mark R Brent. Harvard University, 1981. (Thesis http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/77003423) * ''An Evaluation of the Relevance of the Kübler-Ross Model to the Post-injury Responses of Competitive Athletes'', Johannes Hendrikus Van der Poel, [[University of the Free State]]. Published by s.n., 2000. ==External links== * [http://www.ekrfoundation.org/ Elisabeth Kübler-Ross Foundation] * [http://dying.about.com/od/glossary/g/DABDA.htm DABDA: The Five Stages of Coping With Death] – about.com * [http://www.healthy.net/scr/interview.aspx?Id=205 "On Death and Dying"] – interview with Elisabeth Kübler-Ross M.D. * [http://home.windstream.net/overbeck/grfbrf13.html "Beware the Five Stages of 'Grief{{'"}}] – TLC Group editorial {{DEFAULTSORT:Kubler-Ross Model}} [[Category:Grief]] [[Category:Psychological theories]] [[Category:Psychology books]] [[Category:Self-help books]] [[Category:Stage theories]]

revision.text:
Maternal death or maternal mortality is defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as "the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes." The maternal mortality rate, on the other hand, is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 births. The maternal mortality is used as a criterion for the quality of medical care in a country. == List == Countries by maternal mortality rate in the year 2015. All data is from the [[World Bank]].{{cite web|title=Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate, per 100,000 live births) {{!}} Data|periodical=|publisher=|url=https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.STA.MMRT?locations=FI-VE&year_high_desc=false|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2018-06-27|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=en-us|pages=|quote=}} {| class="wikitable" !Rank !Country !Maternal mortality ratio

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Maria Caterina Farnese | image = Matteo Loves 1610-1662 - Maria Farnese - Musée d'Art et d'Histoire, Geneva.jpg | succession = [[Duchess of Modena and Reggio]] | reign = 11 January 1631 – 25 July 1646 | reign-type = Tenure | spouse = [[Francesco I d'Este, Duke of Modena]] | issue = [[Alfonso IV d'Este, Duke of Modena|Alfonso IV, Duke of Modena]]
[[Isabella d'Este (1635–1666)|Isabella, Duchess of Parma]]
[[Maria of Modena|Maria, Duchess of Parma]] | full name = Maria Caterina Farnese | issue-link = #Issue | house = [[House of Farnese|Farnese]] | father = [[Ranuccio I Farnese, Duke of Parma]] | mother = [[Margherita Aldobrandini]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1615|2|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Parma]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1646|7|25|1615|2|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Ducal Palace of Sassuolo]], [[Modena]] }} '''Maria Caterina Farnese''' (18 February 1615 – 25 July 1646) was a member of the [[Ducal]] [[House of Farnese]]. She was the [[Duchess of Modena]] as the first wife of [[Francesco I d'Este, Duke of Modena]]. In some sources she is known simply as ''Maria Farnese''. ==Biography== Born in [[Parma]] to [[Ranuccio I Farnese, Duke of Parma]] and his wife, ''Donna'' [[Margherita Aldobrandini]], she was the couples sixth child and second daughter.{{cite web|url= http://www.genealogics.org/getperson.php?personID=I00002971&tree=LEO |title=Maria Caterina Farnese|accessdate= 7 April 2010|last= van de Pas|first= Leo|work= Genealogics.org}} Her older brother [[Odoardo Farnese, Duke of Parma|Odoardo Farnese]] was later the [[Duke of Parma]]. Her mother was [[Margherita Aldobrandini]], daughter of Gianfrancesco and [[Olimpia Aldobrandini (1567–1637)|Olimpia Aldobrandini]] who in turn, was a member of the [[Aldobrandini family|House of Aldobrandini]] of [[Rome]], and the sole heiress to the family fortune. She was a proposed bride of [[Charles II of England]]{{cite web|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=dsyKSuLgEbcC&pg=PA30&dq=maria+caterina+farnese&hl=en&ei=E-YcTOTJA46V4gbE38WcDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=maria%20caterina%20farnese&f=false |title= Lorenzo Magalotti at the court of Charles II |accessdate= 7 April 2010|last= Knowles Middleton|first= William Edgar |work= Googlebooks.org}} but the marriage plans never materialised Charles instead married [[Catherine of Braganza]]. She was engaged to [[Francesco I d'Este, Duke of Modena]], son of the defunct [[Alfonso III d'Este, Duke of Modena]] and [[Princess]] [[Isabella of Savoy]]. She married Francesco on 11 January 1631 in [[Parma]]; the marriage produced nine children, three of which went on to have progeny. She died in July 1646 having give birth to a son. She died at the [[Ducal Palace of Sassuolo]] outside Modena, the summer residence of the Dukes of Modena. Her nephew [[Ranuccio II Farnese, Duke of Parma]] married two of Maria Caterina's daughters, [[Isabella d'Este (1635–1666)|Isabella]] in 1664 and [[Maria d'Este|Maria]] in 1668. Isabella died in childbirth like her mother. Her husband married again twice, firstly to her sister [[Vittoria Farnese]] in 1648 and then to Lucrezia Barberini who was the mother of [[Rinaldo d'Este, Duke of Modena]]. ==Issue== #Alfonso d'Este, Hereditary Prince of Modena (1632) died in infancy. #[[Alfonso IV d'Este, Duke of Modena]] (2 February 1634 – 16 July 1662) married [[Laura Martinozzi]] and had issue. #[[Isabella d'Este (1635–1666)|Isabella d'Este]] (3 October 1635 – 21 August 1666) married [[Ranuccio II Farnese, Duke of Parma]] and had issue. #Leonore d'Este (1639–1640) died in infancy. #Tedald d'Este (1640–1643) died in infancy. #Almerigo d'Este (8 May 1641 – 14 November 1660) died unmarried. #[[Eleonora d'Este (1643-1722)|Eleonora d'Este]] (1643 – 24 February 1722) died unmarried. #[[Maria of Modena|Maria d'Este]] (8 December 1644 – 20 August 1684) married [[Ranuccio II Farnese, Duke of Parma]] and had issue. #Tedald d'Este (1646) died in infancy. ==Titles and styles== *'''18 February 1615 – 11 January 1631:''' ''[[Highness|Her Highness]]'' Maria Caterina Farnese, Princess of Parma *'''11 January 1631 – 25 July 1646:''' ''Her Highness'' The Duchess of Modena ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= {{nowrap|1. '''Maria Caterina Farnese'''}} |2= 2. [[Ranuccio I Farnese, Duke of Parma]] |3= 3. [[Margherita Aldobrandini]] |4= 4. [[Alexander Farnese, Duke of Parma|Alessandro Farnese, Duke of Parma]] |5= 5. [[Infanta Maria of Guimarães|Maria of Portugal]] |6= 6. Giovanni Francesco Aldobrandini |7= 7. Olimpia Aldobrandini |8= 8. [[Ottavio Farnese, Duke of Parma]] |9= 9. [[Margaret of Parma|Margaret of Austria]] |10= 10. [[Duarte of Portugal, 4th Duke of Guimarães|Edward, Duke of Guimarães]] |11= 11. [[Isabel of Braganza]] |12= 12. Giorgio Aldobrandini |13= 13. Margherita del Corno |14= 14. Pietro Aldobrandini |15= 15. Flaminia Ferracci |16= 16. [[Pier Luigi Farnese, Duke of Parma]] |17= 17. [[Gerolama Orsini]] |18= 18.
