{{Infobox writer | name = Álvares de Azevedo | image = Álvares de Azevedo.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = A picture of Azevedo taken during the late 1840s | pseudonym = Job Stern | birth_name = Manuel Antônio Álvares de Azevedo | birth_date = {{Birth date|1831|9|12|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[São Paulo]], [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]], [[Empire of Brazil|Brazil]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1852|4|25|1831|9|12|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil | resting_place = [[Cemitério de São João Batista|Saint John the Baptist Cemetery]], Rio de Janeiro, Brazil | occupation = [[Poetry|Poet]], [[playwright]], [[short story]] writer, [[essay]]ist, [[Law]] student | language = Portuguese | nationality = Brazilian | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of São Paulo]] | period = 19th century | genre = [[Theatre]], [[poetry]], [[essay]] | subject = | movement = [[Romanticism]], [[Ultra-Romanticism]] | notableworks = ''[[Noite na Taverna]]''
''[[Macário]]''
''[[Lira dos Vinte Anos]]'' | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = Inácio Manuel Álvares de Azevedo (father)
Maria Luísa Mota Azevedo (mother) | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = }} '''Manuel Antônio Álvares de Azevedo''' (September 12, 1831 – April 25, 1852), affectionately called "'''Maneco'''" by his close friends, relatives and admirers, was a [[Brazil]]ian [[Romanticism|Romantic]] poet, short story writer, playwright and essayist, considered to be one of the major exponents of [[Ultra-Romanticism]] and [[Gothic fiction|Gothic literature]] in Brazil. His works tend to play heavily with opposite notions, such as love and death, [[Platonic love|platonism]] and sarcasm, [[Sentimentalism (literature)|sentimentalism]] and [[pessimism]], among others, and have a strong influence of [[Alfred de Musset|Musset]], [[François-René de Chateaubriand|Chateaubriand]], [[Alphonse de Lamartine|Lamartine]], [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] and – above all – [[Lord Byron|Byron]]. All of his works were published posthumously due to his premature death with only 20 years old after a horse-riding accident. They acquired a strong [[cult following]] as years went by, particularly among youths of the [[goth subculture]]. He is the patron of the second chair of the [[Academia Brasileira de Letras|Brazilian Academy of Letters]], and of the ninth chair of the [[Academia Paulista de Letras|Paulista Academy of Letters]]. ==Biography== Azevedo was born into a wealthy family in [[São Paulo]], on September 12, 1831. Son of [[Law]] student Inácio Manuel Álvares de Azevedo and Maria Luísa Azevedo (''née'' Mota), a popular myth says that he was given birth in the library of the [[Faculdade de Direito da Universidade de São Paulo|University of São Paulo Law School]], but it actually happened on the house of his maternal grandfather, Severo Mota.[http://www.academia.org.br/abl/cgi/cgilua.exe/sys/start.htm?sid=93 Álvares de Azevedo – Academia Brasileira de Letras] {{pt icon}} He also had a sister and a younger brother, Inácio Manuel Júnior, but he died prematurely in 1835. The death proved to be an early source of shock for the young Álvares. In 1833, Álvares moved with his family to [[Rio de Janeiro]], and in 1840 he enrolled at the Colégio Stoll, in the ''[[bairro]]'' of [[Botafogo]].{{cite web |url=http://educacao.uol.com.br/biografias/alvares-de-azevedo.jhtm |title=Álvares de Azevedo |accessdate=27 March 2012 |author=UOL Educação }} In 1844 he temporarily returned to São Paulo with his uncle, going back to Rio in the following year, where he enrolled at the [[Colégio Pedro II]]. There he learned [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and [[German language|German]], and, being a very avid reader, got acquainted with the works of [[Lord Byron]], [[François-René de Chateaubriand]], [[Victor Hugo]], [[George Sand]], [[William Shakespeare]], [[John Keats]], [[Manuel Maria Barbosa du Bocage|Manuel du Bocage]], [[Dante Alighieri]], [[Alfred de Musset]], [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]], [[Alphonse de Lamartine]] and [[Thomas Chatterton]], which would heavily influence his writing style. Having graduated in 1846 from the Colégio Pedro II, he was admitted to the [[Faculdade de Direito da Universidade de São Paulo|University of São Paulo Law School]] in the following year, where he befriended poets [[José Bonifácio the Younger]] (the grandnephew of famous Brazilian [[politician|statesman]] [[José Bonifácio de Andrada|José Bonifácio de Andrada e Silva]]), [[Aureliano Lessa]] and [[Bernardo Guimarães]]. Alongside these poets and others, he founded the infamous "Sociedade Epicureia" ("[[Epicurus|Epicurean]] Society"), a mythical club heavily based upon [[Epicureanism|Epicurean]] and [[Bohemianism|bohemian]] thought, and also planned a work in conjunction with Lessa and Guimarães, the poetry book ''As Três Liras'' (''The Three Lyres'').{{cite web |url=http://www.mundoeducacao.com.br/literatura/alvares-azevedopoeta-ultrarromantico.htm |title=Álvares de Azevedo – O poeta ultrarromântico |accessdate=27 March 2012 |publisher=Mundo Educação}} However, the ''As Três Liras'' project never came to be; the only surviving part of it today is the book ''[[Lira dos Vinte Anos]]'', published one year after Azevedo's death, in 1853. He also founded in 1849 the official magazine of the Sociedade Ensaio Filosófico Paulistano, whose publication ceased in 1856. Because of his fragile health and the murky weather of São Paulo, Azevedo contracted [[tuberculosis]]. He then abandoned college and moved to his grandfather's farm in Rio, where the weather was warmer, in order to mitigate his disease's symptoms; there he fell from a [[horse]] and fractured his [[iliac fossa]]. After an unsuccessful surgery, he died, on April 25, 1852, being only 20 years old.{{cite web |url=http://www.itaucultural.org.br/aplicexternas/enciclopedia_lit/index.cfm?fuseaction=biografias_texto&cd_verbete=4950&cd_item=35 |title=Azevedo, Álvares de (1831–1852) |accessdate=27 March 2012 |author=Enciclopédia Itaú Cultural }} He was buried one day later at the [[Cemitério de São João Batista|Saint John the Baptist Cemetery]]; his last words before his death were reported to be "Que fatalidade, meu pai!" ("What a fatality, my father!"). Ironically, one of the last poems Azevedo wrote prior to his death was entitled "Se Eu Morresse Amanhã" ("If I Died Tomorrow") – the poem was read at his funeral by [[Manuel Antônio de Almeida]], who also happened to be one of Azevedo's cousins. Another one of Azevedo's cousins, Maria Catarina de Abreu Sodré, eventually married famous novelist [[Joaquim Manuel de Macedo]], who allegedly based the character Carolina of his novel ''[[A Moreninha]]'' on her. ==Works== * ''[[Lira dos Vinte Anos]]'' (1853; poetry [[anthology]]) * ''[[Macário]]'' (1855; [[play (theatre)|theater play]]) * ''[[Noite na Taverna]]'' (1855; [[short story]] book, under pen name '''Job Stern''') * ''O Conde Lopo'' (1886; an [[Epic poetry|epic poem]] that remains only in fragments today) * ''O Poema do Frade'' (1890; [[Narrative poetry|narrative poem]]) Azevedo also wrote many letters and essays, and translated into [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] numerous poems by [[Victor Hugo]], [[Lord Byron]]'s "[[Parisina]]", [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Othello]]''{{'}}s fifth act and [[Heinrich Heine]]'s poem "Sag' mir wer einst die Uhren erfund" (present in his ''Lira dos Vinte Anos'' under the title "Relógios e Beijos"). He also wrote a novel, ''O Livro de Fra. Gondicário''; however, the only extant parts of it today are two fragments of its third chapter. ==Representations in popular culture== * Azevedo is the main character of Mário Teixeira's 2009 [[Young adult fiction|young adult novel]] ''Alma de Fogo'' ({{ISBN|9788508126774}}). The novel's premise is that a [[serial killer]] is on the loose in the streets of São Paulo, and Azevedo decides to investigate alongside his friends Aureliano Lessa and Bernardo Guimarães. * ''[[Noite na Taverna]]'' was adapted into [[Noite na Taverna#Adaptations|a film]] in 2014, in which Azevedo appears as a character portrayed by Victor Mendes. * A semi-fictionalized biography of Azevedo, ''Delírio, Poesia e Morte'' ({{ISBN|9788564590861}}), was written by Luciana Fátima and released on June 27, 2015 through Editora Estronho. Fátima previously wrote a lengthy essay regarding Azevedo's life and ''œuvre'' in 2009, entitled ''Álvares de Azevedo: O Poeta que Não Conheceu o Amor Foi Noivo da Morte'' ({{ISBN|9788574199047}}). * A 2014 [[Children's literature|children's book]] by Márcia Abreu, ''Morrer Amanhã'' ({{ISBN|9788532290908}}), elaborates a story based on the friendship between Azevedo and a fictional character, the [[Slavery in Brazil|Afro-Brazilian slave]] Tonico. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * ALVES, Maria C. R. ''O Poeta-Leitor: Um Estudo das Epígrafes Hugoanas em Álvares de Azevedo''. USP, 1999. * BELÚZIO, Rafael Fava. ''Uma Lira de Duas Cordas''. SCRIPTUM, 2015. * CUNHA, Cilaine Alves. ''O Belo e o Disforme''. EDUSP, 2000. * CUNHA, Cilaine Alves. ''Entusiasmo Indianista e Ironia Byroniana''. EDUSP, 2000. * FÁTIMA, Luciana. ''Álvares de Azevedo: O Poeta que Não Conheceu o Amor Foi Noivo da Morte''. Annablume, 2009. ==External links== {{Wikisourcelang|pt|Autor:Álvares de Azevedo|Álvares de Azevedo (original works in Portuguese)}} * [http://www.academia.org.br/abl/cgi/cgilua.exe/sys/start.htm?sid=93 Álvares de Azevedo's biography at the official site of the Brazilian Academy of Letters] {{pt icon}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Manuel Antônio Álvares de Azevedo}} * {{Librivox author |id=2088}} * [http://www.spectrumgothic.com.br/literatura/epicureia.htm About the Epicurean Society] {{pt icon}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box|title=[[File:Olivenkranz.png|20px]]
